answers.content_html: The rate of voltage oscillation increases as the particle travels faster and faster on each loop.
answers.feedback_html: The rate of voltage oscillation increases as the particle travels faster and faster on each loop.

answers.content_html: The rate of voltage oscillation decreases as the particle travels faster and faster on each loop.
answers.feedback_html: The rate of voltage oscillation does not decrease, as the particle travels faster and faster on each loop.

answers.content_html: The rate of voltage oscillation remains the same each time the particle completes a loop.
answers.feedback_html: The rate of voltage oscillation does not remain the same, as the particle travels faster and faster on each loop.

answers.content_html: The rate of voltage oscillation first increases and then remains constant each time the particle completes a loop.
answers.feedback_html: The rate of voltage oscillation increases, but it does not remain constant.

stem_html: What happens to the rate of voltage oscillation within a synchrotron each time the particle completes a loop?

answers.feedback_html: Accelerating capacity increases with increasing electric potential for a Van de Graaff generator.
Accelerating capacity decreases with decreasing electric potential for a Van de Graaff generator.

answers.content_html: The accelerating capacity of a Van de Graaff generator is constant regardless of electric potential.
answers.feedback_html: The electric potential is related to the accelerating capacity of the generator.

answers.content_html: Van de Graaff generators do not have the capacity to accelerate particles.
answers.feedback_html: Van de Graaff generators do accelerate particles.

stem_html: What effect does an increase in electric potential have on the accelerating capacity of a Van de Graaff generator?

answers.content_html: Carrier particles carry mass from one location to another within a force field.
answers.feedback_html: Mass is not necessarily carried by carrier particles.

answers.content_html: Carrier particles carry force from one location to another within a force field.
answers.feedback_html: Carrier particles carry force from one location to another within a force field.

answers.content_html: Carrier particles carry charge from one location to another within a force field.
answers.feedback_html: Charge is not always carried by carrier particles

answers.content_html: Carrier particles carry volume from one location to another within a force field.
answers.feedback_html: Volume is not carried by carrier particles.

stem_html: How do carrier particles relate to the concept of a force field?

answers.content_html: By using a large radius, high particle velocities can be achieved using a large centripetal force created by large electromagnets.
answers.feedback_html: The design strategy is to reduce, not utilize, centripetal force.

answers.content_html: By using a large radius, high particle velocities can be achieved without a large centripetal force created by large electromagnets.
answers.feedback_html: The high energies needed in a synchrotron can only be achieved by fast-moving particles, and centripetal force can be reduced with a larger radius.

answers.content_html: By using a large radius, the velocities of particles can be reduced without a large centripetal force created by large electromagnets.
answers.feedback_html: The purpose is not to reduce the velocities.

answers.content_html: By using a large radius, the acceleration of particles can be decreased without a large centripetal force created by large electromagnets.
answers.feedback_html: By using a large radius, high velocities can be achieved. This is possible only when acceleration increases.

stem_html: Why are synchrotrons constructed to be very large?
